title: [MNT] how to deal with problematic base class imports

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Restructuring without changing its external behavior. Neither fixing a bug nor adding a feature.

body:
There seems to be no structure to the placement of individual package base classes (or if there is, it is very broad). Most are situated in the main package folder i.e. `sktime.classification.base.py`, but the files surrounding the base classes and their availability in the `__init__.py` file will change from package to package. 

For base classes which are in an `__init__.py` with other estimators or situated in a subpackage, any imports will also import the surrounding estimators. While rather niche, this can possibly lead to situations like the one seen in #3634 where unrelated estimators are being imported through base class imports in the `registry` package.

I think it would be better to have a similar structure for all packages.

A few ideas, though feel free to suggest others:

1. Move base classes to the `base` package, i.e. `from sktime.base import BaseForecaster` or `from sktime.base._base import BaseForecaster`. Possibly in subpackages i.e. `from sktime.base.forecasting import BaseForecaster` or `from sktime.base.forecasting._base import BaseForecaster`.
2. Place the files in the main package i.e. `from sktime.forecasting import BaseForecaster` or `from sktime.forecasting._base import BaseForecaster`. This would require no files other than the base class to use the top level `__init__.py`.
3. Have base class subpackages i.e. `from sktime.forecasting.base import BaseForecaster` or `from sktime.forecasting.base._base import BaseForecaster`. This also requires no top level `__init__.py` usage.
4. Do nothing.
